Class Query

  • java.lang.Object
    • Query

  • public class Query
extends java.lang.Object
    The Query class represents a parsed SQL query as specified by Milestone 1 documentation.

    Basic Rules
    NO SPACING allowed in the following cases
    1. In field names or values inserted with the INSERT query. If you wish to have two (or more) word phrases use underscores.
    2. Between field names or values inserted with the INSERT query. Use a comma and do not place any sort of spacing before or after the comma.
    3. Around an '=' sign there should be no spaces as well. This applies to the 'SET' clause of UPDATE as well as the 'ID' part of WHERE clause.
    4. Between the terminating semicolon ';' and the preceeding statement

    Remember that queries must end with a semicolon!

    If you violate any of these rules your query will be considered invalid and will not be parsed.

    Good Query Examples
    • SELECT * FROM employees;
    • SELECT field1,field2 FROM employees;
    • SELECT field1,field2 FROM employees WHERE id=2;
    • INSERT INTO employees VALUES (tom,jones,20,$344);
    • UPDATE employees SET last=jordan;
    • UPDATE employees SET last=jordan WHERE id=5;
    • DELETE FROM employees;
    • DELETE FROM employees WHERE id=6;

    BAD Query Examples
    • SELECT * FROM employees ; // violates rule 4
    • SELECT field1, field2 FROM employees; // violates rule 1
    • SELECT field1,last name FROM employees; // violates rule 2
    • SELECT field1,field2 FROM employees WHERE id =2; // violates rule 3
    • INSERT INTO employees VALUES (tom joseph,jones smith,20,$344); // violates rule 1
    • UPDATE employees SET last=jordan // semicolon missing!
    • UPDATE employees SET last= jordan WHERE id=5; // violates rule 3

    Version:
    1.0, April 2015
    Author:
    Pawel Szczurko (pszczurko@gmail.com)

    • Method Detail

      • getSelectFields

        public java.lang.String[] getSelectFields()
        Once query has been parsed, this returns a String array with the fields found in a SELECT query.

        NOTE: Make sure to first verify that your parsed query is a SELECT query. If it is not, this method returns null.
        Returns:
        String array of SELECT fields if current query in fact is a SELECT query, null otherwise.

      • getInsertValues

        public java.lang.String[] getInsertValues()
        Once query has been parsed, this returns a String array with the values found in INSERT query.

        NOTE: Make sure to first verify that your parsed query is an INSERT query. If it is not, this method returns null.
        Returns:
        String array of INSERT values if current query in fact is an INSERT query, null otherwise.

      • getUpdateField

        public java.lang.String getUpdateField()
        Once query has been parsed, this returns a String representing the 'field' in the UPDATE query.

        Ex: For the query "UPDATE employees SET last=jordan;", this method will return 'last' since it is the 'field' specified in this query.

        NOTE: Make sure to first verify that your parsed query is an UPDATE query. If it is not, this method returns null.
        Returns:
        String representation of the 'field' specified in the current query if it is an UPDATE query, returns null otherwise.

      • getUpdateValue

        public java.lang.String getUpdateValue()
        Once query has been parsed, this returns a String representing the 'value' in the UPDATE query.

        Ex: For the query "UPDATE employees SET last=jordan;", this method will return 'jordan' since it is the 'value' specified in this query.

        NOTE: Make sure to first verify that your parsed query is an UPDATE query. If it is not, this method returns null.
        Returns:
        String representation of the 'value' specified in the current query if it is an UPDATE query, returns null otherwise.

      • getWhereID

        public int getWhereID()
        Fetches the 'ID' field specified in the WHERE part of the query.
        Returns:
        int representing the 'ID' field if one was found, returns -1 if no WHERE clause was present.

      • getRelationName

        public java.lang.String getRelationName()
        Fetches the relation/table name from the query.
        Returns:
        String representing the relation/table name specified in the query. If an error occurred or no relation/table name was found then NOT FOUND is returned.

      • isSelect

        public boolean isSelect()
        Method used to check if parsed query is a SELECT query
        Returns:
        boolean that returns 'true' if it is a SELECT query, 'false' otherwise.

      • isUpdate

        public boolean isUpdate()
        Method used to check if parsed query is an UPDATE query
        Returns:
        boolean that returns 'true' if it is an UPDATE query, 'false' otherwise.

      • isDelete

        public boolean isDelete()
        Method used to check if parsed query is a DELETE query
        Returns:
        boolean that returns 'true' if it is a DELETE query, 'false' otherwise.

      • isInsert

        public boolean isInsert()
        Method used to check if parsed query is an INSERT query
        Returns:
        boolean that returns 'true' if it is an INSERT query, 'false' otherwise.

      • readQuery

        public static Query readQuery()
        Static method that repeatedly prompts a user for a query until a correctly formatted query is inputted. The method returns a Query object in the same way the the IO.java module returns the requested type.

        Basic usage: Query myQuery = Query.readQuery();
        Returns:
        Query type is returned, a return value of null should never occur.

      • readQuery

        public static Query readQuery(java.lang.String q)
        Static method that analyzes the passed query and attempts to parse and return it in Query object form. This method might be useful for developing so that way a query can be typed into the source code.

        The main difference between the other readQuery method and this one is that there is no continuous prompting for a new query so this method will return null if an incorrectly formatted query has been passed.

        Basic usage: Query myQuery = Query.readQuery("select * from employees;");
        Returns:
        Query type is returned, a return value of null will be present if an incorrectly formatted query has been passed.
